description: From Middle English queynte, quoynte, from Anglo-Norman cointe, queinte and Old French cointe (“pretty, clever, knowing”), from Latin cognitus, past participle of cognōscō (“I know”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Of a person: cunning, crafty. [13th–19th c.]
(now dialectal) Strange or odd; unusual. [from 14th c.]
examples: What none would dispute though many smiled over was the good-humored, necessary, yet quaint omission of the writer's name from the whole consideration.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Overly discriminating or needlessly meticulous; fastidious; prim. [15th–19th c.]
Pleasingly unusual; especially, having old-fashioned charm. [from 18th c.]
examples: The rock is a haven for rare wildlife, a landscape where pretty hedgerows and quaint villages are bordered by a breathtaking, craggy coastline.

description: A variant of cunt (possibly as a pun).

examples: The rest looked on, horrified, as Clarice trussed up her habit and in open view placed her hand within her queynte crying, ‘The first house of Sunday belongs to the sun, and the second to Venus.’
